Authors:
Xuan Wang, Tingting Wang, Jingcheng Wang, Tinglong Guan,
Hongmei Li
Title:
Morphological, molecular and biological characterization of a
nematophagous endoparasitic fungus strain Esteya vermicola from
Brazil
Keywords:
Esteya vermicola, Infection, Morphology, Nematophagous
endoparasite, Phylogeny
Abstract:
The nematophagous endoparasitic strain NKF 13222 was
purified from Bursaphelenchus rainulfi which was intercepted from Brazil
wood packagings at Tianjin Port in China. The fungus produced two types
of conidiogenous cells and conidia. The nutrient-poor WA medium can
produce much more lunate adhesive conidia than bacilloid conidia. The
dimorphic conidia have different germination mode. Morphological
comparison revealed the Brazil strain is more close to the Taiwan strain
ATCC 74485 of Esteya vermicola isolated from pine wood nematode
Bursaphelenchus xylophilus. Phylogenetic analysis of beta-tubulin gene
and Elongation Factor 1-Î± gene revealed NKF 13222 strain grouped with
the reported strains of E. vermicola into a clear clade with high
support values (100 BP, 1.00 BPP), and NKF 13222 was closed to ATCC
74485 within different strains of E. vermicola. The results confirmed
the taxonomic identification of Brazilian NKF 13222 as a new strain of
E. vermicola. This was the first isolation of E. vermicola from B.
rainulfi in South America. The infection test against several plant
parasitic nematodes demonstrated NKF 13222 presented high infectivity to
aphelenchids instead of tylenchid nematodes and only lunate adhesive
conidia showed the parasitic ability. The results suggest that the
fungus might be a pathogen of aphelenchid nematodes with broad
distribution. The study of NKF 13222 strain provided the useful
information for biocontrol potency in plant diseases caused by B.
xylophilus and Aphelenchoides spp..
